chunks.original_text: 三十辐章第十一 三十辐共一毂，当其无，有车之用； 涎坛以为器，当其无，有器之用； 凿户牖以为室，当其无，有室之用。 徽宗注曰：有无一政，利用出入，是谓至神。 有无异相，在有为体，在无为用，阴阳之运，万物之理也。 车之用在运，器之用在盛，室之用在虚，妙用出於至无，变化藏於不累，如镒无象，因物显照，至人用心，每解乎此。 疏义曰：即至神以观之，意其有而非有，意其无而非无，冥有与无而利用皆所自出入，则有无一致，利用出入，是谓至神也。 即阴阳万物以观之，显而可见，斯谓之有； 幽而不测，斯谓之无。 别有无於异相，在有为体，在无为用，阴阳之运，万物之理也。 故三十辐共一毂，涎坛以为器，凿户牖以为室，皆显於有者也，车与器室利在是焉。 然车之所以运，器之所以盛，室之所以虚，果何物哉？ 妙用出於至无，而莫睹其端倪； 变化藏於不累，而莫窥其畛域。 如镒无像，因物显照，不将不迎，应而不藏，固非有也，亦非无也，应物而不伤斯已矣。 至人用心，每解乎此。 故有之以为利，无之以为用。 徽宗注曰：有则实，无则虚，实故具貌像声色而有质，虚故能运量酬醉而不穷。 天地之间，道以器显，故无不废有； 器以道妙，故有必归无。 木挠而水润，火焕而金坚，土均而布，稼穑出焉，此有也，而人赖以为利。 天之所以运，地之所以处，四时之所以行，百物之所以昌，孰尸之者？ 此无也。 而世莫睹其述，故其用不匮。 有无之相生，老氏於此三者，推而明之。 疏义曰：有则有碍，无适非实； 无则无间，无适非虚。 实故具貌像声色而有质，有之以为利故也。 虚故能运量酬醉而不穷，无之以为用故也。 目道而降域於两间，形而上者不离於有，在无亦显也，故道以器显，无不废有； 形而下者不外於无，在有亦藏也，故器以道妙，有必归无。 散为五行，水火为用，金木为器，土谷为利，木挠而水润，火焕而金坚，土均而布，稼穑出焉。 凡在天地之问，孰不资焉？ 故人赖以为利。 降於域中，天其运乎，地其处乎，四时行焉，百物生焉，若有机缄而不得已，若运转而不能自止，孰尸之者？ 皆天也。 故世莫睹其进焉，虽然，无即妙有，有即真无，有无相生，若循环然。 天地之大，秋毫之小，未有逃此者。 即车之运，器之盛，室之容以明之，几天下之物所以运，所以盛，所以容可以类知矣。 老氏於斯三者，推而明之，举一以知万故也。 五色章第十二 五色令人目盲，五音令人耳聋， 徽宗注曰：目围二焉，其见者性也，彻而为明则作哲，足以断天下之疑。 耳藏一焉，其闻者性也，彻而为聪则作谋，足以通天下之志。 睹道之人，无形之上，独以神视，无声之表，独以气听，而视听有不待耳目之用者，曾何声色之足蔽哉？ 世之人役耳目於外物之累，故目淫於五色，耳淫於五音，而聪明为之衰，其於盲聋也何辩？ 疏义曰：离再索得女，外奇内耦，其象为目，则目围二也。 取诸八物为火，火则其光外景，故在性为见。 目彻为明，明以作哲，故足以断天下之疑，五色孰得以乱其明？ 坎再索得男，外耦内奇，其象为耳，则耳藏一也。 取诸八物为水，水则其明内烛，故在性为闻。 耳彻为聪，聪以作谋，故足以通天下之志，五音孰得以汨其聪？
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Eleven: The Thirty Spokes**

Thirty spokes converge at a single hub—
when the hub is empty, the carriage’s use is complete.
Mold clay into a vessel—
when the vessel is empty, its use is complete.
Carve doors and windows for a dwelling—
when the dwelling is empty, its use is complete.

Emperor Huizong’s annotation:
The interplay of presence and absence is the ultimate principle—
utility emerges from their interplay.
Presence and absence differ in form:
presence as substance, absence as function—
the operation of yin and yang, the logic of all things.

The carriage’s use lies in motion,
the vessel’s in containment,
the dwelling’s in emptiness.
Mysterious utility arises from the utmost absence,
transformation is concealed in non-attachment—
like a balance without form,
manifesting through things yet unseen.
The Perfect Person’s mind ever resolves this truth.

Explanatory commentary:
Observing the ultimate principle,
one perceives presence yet it is not truly present,
absence yet it is not truly absent.
In the interplay of presence and absence,
all utility arises—
thus presence and absence align,
utility flows—
this is the ultimate principle.

Observing yin and yang, all things:
what is manifest and visible is called presence,
what is obscure and unfathomable is called absence.
Distinguishing presence and absence in their forms—
presence as substance, absence as function—
the operation of yin and yang, the logic of all things.

Thus thirty spokes converge at a hub,
clay is shaped into vessels,
doors and windows are carved for dwellings—
all are manifest in presence,
and utility lies therein.
Yet what enables the carriage to move,
the vessel to contain,
the dwelling to be empty?
Mysterious utility arises from the utmost absence,
yet no trace is seen;
transformation is concealed in non-attachment,
yet no boundary is glimpsed.
Like a balance without form,
manifesting through things yet unseen—
neither forcing nor resisting,
responding yet not hoarding—
neither presence nor absence,
yet adapting to things without harm.
The Perfect Person’s mind ever resolves this truth.

Thus presence is for utility,
absence is for function.

Emperor Huizong’s annotation:
Presence is solid, absence is void—
solidity possesses form, likeness, sound, color, and substance,
voidness enables motion, measure, response, and fulfillment without end.
Between Heaven and Earth,
the Dao manifests through vessels,
thus absence never abandons presence;
vessels embody the Dao’s mystery,
thus presence inevitably returns to absence.
Wood bends, water moistens,
fire radiates, metal hardens,
earth balances, and grains emerge—
this is presence, yet humanity relies on it for utility.
Heaven’s motion, Earth’s stability,
the seasons’ progression, all things flourishing—
who governs this?
This is absence.
Yet the world fails to perceive its operation,
so its utility is inexhaustible.

Presence and absence generate each other—
Laozi elucidates these three principles.
Explanatory commentary:
Presence entails obstruction, absence is not mere emptiness;
absence entails continuity, yet is not mere void.
Solidity possesses form, likeness, sound, color, and substance—
thus presence is for utility.
Voidness enables motion, measure, response, and fulfillment without end—
thus absence is for function.
The Dao descends into the dual realm:
above form, it does not depart from presence,
yet presence also reveals it—
thus the Dao manifests through vessels,
absence never abandons presence.
Below form, it does not extend beyond absence,
yet presence also conceals it—
thus vessels embody the Dao’s mystery,
presence inevitably returns to absence.

The Five Phases disperse:
water and fire for function,
metal and wood for vessels,
earth and grain for utility.
Wood bends, water moistens,
fire radiates, metal hardens,
earth balances, and grains emerge—
all within Heaven and Earth,
what does not depend on this?
Thus humanity relies on it for utility.

Descending into the realm,
Heaven moves, Earth rests,
the seasons progress, all things thrive—
as if governed by unseen mechanisms,
as if turning yet unable to halt—
who directs this?
It is all Heaven.
Thus the world fails to perceive its operation,
yet absence is true presence,
presence is genuine absence—
presence and absence generate each other,
like a cycle without end.
From the vastness of Heaven and Earth
to the minutiae of autumnal hairs—
nothing escapes this.

Through the carriage’s motion,
the vessel’s containment,
the dwelling’s capacity,
one understands all things under Heaven—
their motion, their containment, their capacity—
by analogy.
Laozi expounds these three principles,
thus one knows ten thousand things from a single example.

**Chapter Twelve: The Five Colors**

The five colors blind the eyes,
the five tones deafen the ears.

Emperor Huizong’s annotation:
The eyes encompass two [yin lines],
their seeing is innate—
penetrating to clarity, wisdom arises,
sufficient to resolve all doubts.
The ears contain one [yang line],
their hearing is innate—
penetrating to acuity, strategy arises,
sufficient to communicate all intentions.
Those who perceive the Dao,
above form, gaze with spirit alone,
beyond sound, listen with qi alone—
what need for ears and eyes?
How could colors and sounds obstruct them?

Explanatory commentary:
Two broken lines yield a female,
yin within, yang without—
this is the symbol of the eyes,
thus the eyes encompass two.
Derived from the eight trigrams as fire,
fire’s light projects outward—
thus innate seeing is vision.
Penetrating vision becomes wisdom,
wisdom resolves all doubts—
what five colors could disrupt this clarity?

A whole line yields a male,
yin without, yang within—
this is the symbol of the ears,
thus the ears contain one.
Derived from the eight trigrams as water,
water’s clarity illuminates within—
thus innate hearing is perception.
Penetrating hearing becomes acuity,
acuity devises strategy,
sufficient to communicate all intentions—
what five tones could drown this clarity?

chunks.original_text: 睹道之人解乎此，造见见之妙，无形之上，独以神视，故能见不见之形； 造闻闻之妙，无声之表，独以气听，故能闻无声之声。 无所不见，无所不闻，视听不用耳目，而所见所闻无适非真，普何声色之足蔽哉？ 世之人所见不能胜，所睹不知闻，和於无声，役耳目於外物之累，悦明而淫於色，孰知天下之正色？ 悦聪而淫於声，孰知天下之大音？ 作聪明而聪明日衰，则不聪实无耳也，不明实无目也，其於聋盲奚择？ 虽然人者自盲聋尔，岂声音之能聋盲人哉。 五味令人口爽，驰骋田猎令人心发狂， 徽宗注曰：道之出口，淡乎其无味。 五味，人之所同嗜也，而厚味实腊毒，故令人。 爽。 人之生也，形不盈仞，而心伴造化。 圣人之心，动而纬万方，静而镒天地。 世之人从事於田猎，而因以丧其良心，不足以自胜，可不谓大哀也耶？ 疏义曰：人食刍豢，麋鹿食荐，鲫蛆食蛇，鸱鸦嗜鼠，四者孰知天下之正味？ 所谓正味，即道之出口淡乎其无味是也。 人皆知味之所味者有同嗜，而不知有味味者存，故以刍豢稻粱为足美。 然而厚味寔腊毒，虽可以养。 体，而失其大体矣。 此五味令人。 爽也。 盖爽，差也，口爽则失其所谓正味矣。 且人之生眇乎小哉，所以属於人，则形不盈仞也。 謷乎大哉，独成其天，则心伴造化也。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who perceive the Dao comprehend this,
and grasp the subtleties of seeing and hearing.
Above form, they gaze with spirit alone—
thus they see what is unseen.
They grasp the subtleties of hearing beyond sound,
beyond voice, they listen with qi alone—
thus they hear what is unsounded.
Seeing nothing unseen, hearing nothing unheard,
their vision and hearing transcend ears and eyes,
yet all they perceive is true—
what sounds or colors could ever obscure them?

Common folk cannot bear what they see,
nor comprehend what they hear.
They harmonize with the unsounded,
enslaved by ears and eyes to external burdens,
delight in brightness yet indulge in color—
who knows the Dao’s true hue?
They delight in acuity yet indulge in sound—
who knows the Dao’s great resonance?

When cleverness fades and wisdom dims,
the deaf are not truly without ears,
the blind are not truly without eyes—
what choice between them?
Yet people blind and deaf themselves—
could sounds and colors make them so?

The five flavors leave the mouth parched,
hunting and chasing drive the heart to madness.
*(Note: The Dao’s utterance is subtle, without taste.)*
The five flavors all share a common craving,
yet rich flavors are truly poisonous—
thus they leave the mouth parched.

Human life is brief, the body small,
yet the heart aligns with the transformations of the cosmos.
The sage’s heart moves and weaves the myriad realms,
stills and balances heaven and earth.

Common folk pursue hunting and chasing,
losing their true nature in the process,
unable to master themselves—
is this not the greatest sorrow?

*(Explanatory commentary:)*
People eat grains and livestock,
deer and elk eat grasses,
minnows and maggots eat snakes,
owls and crows feast on mice—
which knows the Dao’s true flavor?
The true flavor is the Dao’s utterance:
subtle, without taste.

All know the flavors they crave are shared,
yet they do not know the flavor of the Dao exists—
thus they take grains, livestock, and rice as sufficient.
Yet rich flavors are truly poisonous,
though they may nourish the body,
they lose the greater essence.
This is why the five flavors leave the mouth parched.

*(Note: Parched—meaning errant.)*
The mouth parched loses its true flavor.
Moreover, human life is brief and small—
what belongs to humanity is a body not exceeding a few feet,
yet vast is the heart that aligns with the cosmos,
companion to the transformations of nature.

chunks.original_text: 圣人尽心之真，动而纬万方，则周流无问，静而镒天地，则旁烛无疆，方且御六气之辨，以游无穷，尚何从事於田猎之间为哉？ 昧者不知，自胜为强，徒以习驰逐为务，或蹶趋以动其心，而不能自得，良心亦从而丧矣，可不谓大哀耶？ 难得之货令人行妨。 徽宗注曰：利以养人，而货以化之，故交利而俱赡。 圣人不贵难得之货，不贵异物，贱用物，欲人之安其分而无所夺也。 贵难得之货，则至於次性命之情，而饕贵富，何行之能守？ 故令人行妨。 仲虺之称汤曰：不殖货利。 孔子之谓子贡曰：赐不受命而货殖焉。 货之妨行如此。 疏义曰：先王懋迁，有无化居，所以阜通货贿，使交利而俱赡也。 盖利所以养人，而化之则为货，故交利而俱赡。 难得之货，衣之不可衣，食之不可食，苟以是为贵，则至於次性命之情而饕富贵，攘夺诞谩，无所不至，欲民安性命之情，惟行之为守，难矣。 然则圣人不贵异物、贱用物者无他，欲人之安其分而无所夺也。 是以捐金於巉嵁之山，投珠於五湖之渊，不贵难得之货，使人我之养毕足而止，孰有行妨者哉？ 仲虺之称汤曰：不殖货利。 则以动不为利正大人之行也。 孔子谓子贡曰：赐不受命而货殖焉。 则以喻於利非君子之所为也。 庄子所以欲擿玉毁珠，而贵夫不利货财者，以此。 是以圣人为腹不为目，故去彼取此。 徽宗注曰：八卦坤为腹，以厚载而容也。 离为目，以外视而明也。 厚载而容，则无所不受。 外视而明，则有所不及。 圣人以天下为度，故取此能容之腹，非事事而治之，物物而察之也。 故去彼外视之目。 庄子曰：贼莫大於德有心，而心有眼。 故圣人去之。 疏义曰：坤厚载物，含万物而化光，近取诸身则为腹，以厚载而容也。 外阳内阴，明两作为离，近取诸身则为目，以外视而明故也。 厚载而容，则未尝有择，收而积之，亡处亡块，故无所不受。 外视而明，则不能无辨，能见百步之外，而不能自见其睫，故有所不及。 圣人泯是非，一好恶，以天下为度，故取此能容之腹，无所次择，无所去取，非事事而治之，物物而察之也。 故去彼外视之目。 庄子曰：贼莫大於德有心，而心有眼。 盖开天者德生，开人者贼生，心有眼则开人而贼生也，故圣人不为目。 宠辱章第十三 宠辱若惊，贵大患若身。 徽宗注曰：宠者在下，贵者在上，居宠而以为荣，则辱矣。 处贵而以为累，则息莫大焉。 以富为是者，不能辞禄，以显为是者，不能辞名。 亲权者，不能与人柄，操之则栗，舍之则悲，兹宠辱所以若惊欤？ 惨怛之疾，恬愉之安，时集於体，休迫之恐，欣欢之喜，交溺於心，兹大息所以若身欤？ 疏义曰：宠者人之所荣，在下之道也。 贵者人之所累，在上之道也。 居宠而以为荣，则席其宠矣，席其庞则辱。 或随之处贵而以为累，则矜其贵矣，矜其贵则息莫大焉。 以富为是者，不能辞禄，累於厚利故也。 以显为是者，不能辞名，累於高名故也。 亲权者，不能与人柄，以权势不尤，则夸者悲故也。 於是三者操之则栗，所谓既得之，息失之也； 舍之则悲，所谓寄去则不乐也。 兹宠辱所以若惊欤？ 集於体者，非有惨怛之疾，为阴阳之寇，则有恬愉之安。 涉人道之息溺於心者，非有休迫之恐，以毗於阴，则有欣欢之喜，以偏于阳，一身之息丛起交攻，贵而以为之累，其息亦若此而已。
chunks.translated_text:
The Sage exhausts the truth of the heart,
moves and weaves the myriad directions—
then flows unrestricted, without question.
In stillness, he weighs heaven and earth—
then illuminates boundlessly, without limit.
Now he governs the six *qi*’s distinctions,
to wander the boundless—
why then engage in hunting and trapping?

The ignorant do not know:
to conquer oneself is strength.
They labor only in chasing and pursuing,
sometimes stumbling in haste to agitate the heart,
yet cannot find themselves—
and thus lose their true heart.
Is this not called great sorrow?

Rare treasures obstruct one’s conduct.
**Huizong’s Annotation:** *Li* nourishes people, but *huò* transforms them—
thus, when *li* and *huò* interact, both are sustained.

The Sage does not prize rare treasures,
does not prize curiosities,
holds common goods in low regard—
wishing people to rest content in their allotted portion,
without coveting.

To prize rare treasures
leads to neglecting the essence of life and death,
yet gluttonously seeking wealth and rank—
what conduct can endure this?
Thus, rare treasures obstruct one’s path.

**Zhonghu’s praise of Tang** says:
*"Do not cultivate wealth and profit."*
**Confucius told Zigong:**
*"You, Shì, did not receive your mandate yet engage in commerce—"*
So great is the obstruction of wealth to conduct.

**Explanatory Notes** say:
The ancient kings encouraged migration,
harmonizing abundance and scarcity,
to enrich and circulate wealth,
so that *li* and *huò* interact and both are sustained.
Indeed, *li* nourishes people,
but when transformed, it becomes *huò*—
thus, when *li* and *huò* interact, both are sustained.

Rare treasures—
clothing that cannot be worn,
food that cannot be eaten—
if these are prized,
then one neglects the essence of life and death,
yet gluttonously seeks wealth and rank,
plundering and deceiving without restraint.
To make people rest in the essence of life and death,
only conduct can guard this—
how difficult!

Thus, the Sage does not prize curiosities,
holds common goods in low regard—
for no other reason
than to make people content in their portion,
without coveting.

Therefore, he discards gold on the rugged peaks,
casts pearls into the Five Lakes’ depths—
not prizing rare treasures,
so that nourishment for self and others is complete,
and none are obstructed in their path.

**Zhonghu’s praise of Tang** says:
*"Do not cultivate wealth and profit."*
—meaning that *li* should not govern the conduct of the noble.

**Confucius told Zigong:**
*"You, Shì, did not receive your mandate yet engage in commerce—"*
—to admonish that *li* is not the conduct of the gentleman.

**Zhuangzi** desired to shatter jade and destroy pearls,
valuing instead those who do not covet wealth—
for this reason.

Thus, the Sage nourishes the belly, not the eyes—
hence, he discards the latter to take the former.

**Huizong’s Annotation:**
The *guà* of *Kūn* is the belly—
thick and bearing, containing all.
The *guà* of *Lí* are the eyes—
outerly perceiving, brightly discerning.
Thick and bearing, it receives all without discrimination,
collecting and storing—
nothing is left out, nothing is rejected—
thus, it receives without limit.
Outerly perceiving, it cannot help but distinguish—
it sees a hundred paces away,
yet cannot see its own eyelashes—
thus, it has its limits.

The Sage effaces distinctions,
unifies good and evil,
taking the world as measure—
thus, he takes this containing belly,
without partiality or selection,
without taking or discarding,
not governing each matter or scrutinizing each thing.
Hence, he discards those outer-seeing eyes.

**Zhuangzi** said:
*"No thief is greater than virtue with a heart,
and a heart with eyes."*
Thus, the Sage rejects them.

**Explanatory Notes** say:
*Kūn* is thick and bearing, containing all things,
nurturing and transforming with radiance—
taken near to the body, it is the belly,
thick and bearing, containing all.
Outer *yáng*, inner *yīn*—
the two *yáng* make *Lí*, taken near to the body, are the eyes,
outerly perceiving, brightly discerning.

Thick and bearing, it never discriminates—
collecting and storing, nothing is left out, nothing is rejected—
thus, it receives without limit.
Outerly perceiving, it cannot help but distinguish—
it sees a hundred paces away,
yet cannot see its own eyelashes—
thus, it has its limits.

The Sage effaces distinctions,
unifies good and evil,
taking the world as measure—
thus, he takes this containing belly,
without partiality or selection,
without taking or discarding,
not governing each matter or scrutinizing each thing.
Hence, he discards those outer-seeing eyes.

**Zhuangzi** said:
*"No thief is greater than virtue with a heart,
and a heart with eyes."*
Indeed, *dé* opens heaven,
but *zéi* (harm) opens humanity—
a heart with eyes opens humanity and brings harm—
thus, the Sage does not make them eyes.

**Chapter Thirteen: On Honor and Humiliation**
Honor and humiliation are like a startling fright,
great calamities are like a threat to one’s life.

**Huizong’s Annotation:**
Honor is below, rank is above—
to dwell in honor and take it as pride is humiliation.
To dwell in rank and take it as a burden is no greater calamity.
Those who regard wealth as right cannot refuse office,
those who regard eminence as right cannot refuse fame.
Those who cling to power cannot entrust it to others—
to hold it makes one tremble,
to relinquish it brings sorrow.
This is why honor and humiliation are like a startling fright?

Pain and anguish, ease and contentment—
these gather in the body,
urgent dread and joyful delight—
these drown the heart.
This is why great calamities are like a threat to one’s life?

**Explanatory Notes** say:
Honor is what people prize—
the way of those below.
Rank is what people burden themselves with—
the way of those above.
To dwell in honor and take it as pride is to exhaust its fullness—
exhaust its fullness, and it becomes humiliation.
Or, to dwell in rank and take it as a burden is to be proud of one’s rank—
to be proud of one’s rank is no greater calamity.

Those who regard wealth as right cannot refuse office—
burdened by abundant gain.
Those who regard eminence as right cannot refuse fame—
burdened by high renown.
Those who cling to power cannot entrust it to others—
because power and authority are not uniquely theirs,
the proud then grow sorrowful.
Thus, these three:
to hold them brings trembling—
this is *"having gained it, fearing to lose it"*—
to relinquish them brings sorrow—
this is *"parting with it, finding no joy"*—
thus, honor and humiliation are like a startling fright?

What gathers in the body—
if not pain and anguish from the assault of *yīn* and *yáng*,
then ease and contentment.
What drowns the heart in human affairs—
if not urgent dread from proximity to *yīn*,
then joyful delight from leaning toward *yáng*.
The myriad breaths of one’s life rise and clash—
to dwell in rank and take it as a burden,
its calamities are no different.

chunks.original_text: 此大息所以若身欤？ 何谓宠辱？ 宠为下。 徽宗注曰：龙之为物，变化自如，不可制畜，可古覆焉，则志於豢养，有辱之道。 古之善为士者，三旌之位不足易其介，万锺之禄不足迁其守，居宠而思危，在福而若冲，则何辱之有？ 食夫位也，慕夫禄也，知进而不知退，知得而不知丧，则人贱之矣。 故受宠於人，则为下之道。 疏义曰：行天莫如龙，合则成体，散则成章，此变化自如，不可制蓄也。 能见而不能港，未离乎内覆，可豢之以驾驭服乘，则未免有悔，此可古覆焉，则志於豢养，有辱之道也。 宠之所以为辱，以是故尔。 是以善为士者，三旌之位不足易其介，知在我者有贵於三旌之位也。 万锺之禄不足迁其守，知在我者有富於万锺之禄也。 得持宠之术则居宠而思危，知保福之道则在福而若冲，故能富贵不离其身，而福禄能长且久，何辱之有哉？ 苟或食夫位而诬伪以取贵，慕夫禄而责污以取富，知进不知退，昧消长之理，知得不知丧，蔽盈虚之数，则赵孟之贵，赵孟能贱之。 故受宠於人，则为下之道。 得之若惊，失之若惊，是谓宠辱若惊。 徽宗注曰：轩冕在身，非性命之理也。 物之傥来寄也，寄之来不可拒，故至人不以得为悦。 其去不可圉，故至人不以失为忧。 今寄去则不乐，受而喜之，是以得失累乎其心，能勿惊乎？ 柳下惠为士师，三黜而不去，正考父三命，循墙而走，则异於此。 疏义曰：至贵在我，足以并国爵，则轩冕在身，非性命之理也。 外物不可铃，而求无益於得，以物之傥来寄也。 惟时无止，则寄之来不可拒其得之也，於我何加？ 故至人不以得为悦。 惟分无常，则寄之去不可圉，其失之也，於我何损？ 故至人不以失为忧。 昧者不知穷通，如寒暑之序，寄去则不乐，或陨获於贫贱，受而喜之，或充诎於富贵，得失交战於胸中，灵台且为之窒，其不惊者几希。 柳下惠为士师，三黜而不去，正考父三命，循墙而走，岂以得失累其心哉？ 何谓贵大患若身？ 徽宗注曰：据利势，擅赏罚，作福威，天下畏之如神明，尊之如上帝，可谓贵矣。 圣人则不以贵自累，故能长守贵而无息。 譬如人身堕肢体，黜聪明，离形去智，通於大同，则无入而不自得也。 世之人以物易性，故累物而不能忘势，以形累心，故丧心而不能忘形，其患大矣。 疏义曰：以贵自居，未免有息，惟不自有其贵，则可以守贵矣。 犹人之一身，认为己有则动辄有碍，知身非我有，则可以保身矣。 今夫利势之重得以据之，赏罚之权得以檀之，威福之柄得以专之，天下畏之如神明，尊之如上帝，其贵可谓无敌矣。 惟圣人执虚驭满，不以贵自居，则虽贵而无息。 如人之有身，寓百骸以堕肢体，象耳目以黜聪明，离形而不拘於形，去智而不凿以智，则同於大通，造乎不形，无入而不自得也，夫孰以身为息哉？ 妄庸之人不能尽性而志势，累於物以易其性； 不能尽心而忘形，累於形以丧其心。 以物易性，以形累心，其患大矣。 吾所以有大患者，为吾有身。 及吾无身，吾有何患？ 徽宗注曰：人之生也，百骸九窍六脏赅而存焉，吾谁能为亲？ 认而有之，皆惑也。 体道者解乎此，故孔子曰：朝闻道，夕死可矣。 孟子曰：夭寿不二。 颜子曰：回坐忘矣。

「Why does this great *qi* weigh upon one like the body?
What is meant by *"honor and humiliation"*?
Honor is low—
*Huizong*’s annotation says: The dragon, as a creature,
shifts and transforms at will,
unrestrained, impossible to tame.
If it can be covered by the ancient [ritual],
then its spirit is set on domestication—
this is the path of humiliation.

The ancients who excelled in *shi*’s way:
The rank of three *jīng* flags was insufficient to shake their resolve,
the wealth of ten thousand *chóng* measures could not shift their steadfastness.
To dwell in favor yet ponder peril,
to hold fortune yet act as though empty—
then what humiliation could there be?

To covet rank and crave wealth,
to know advancement yet not retreat,
to grasp gain yet not foresee loss—
then one is already debased.
Thus, to receive favor from others
is the way of the lowly.

The *Shūyì* elaborates:
The heavens’ matchless transformations are like the dragon—
united, it forms a body;
scattered, it becomes a pattern.
This is shifting and transforming at will,
unrestrained, impossible to tame.

Unable to see yet unable to contain [its nature],
it has not yet escaped the ancient [ritual]’s cover—
if one strives to domesticate it for harness and riding,
then regret is inevitable.
This is why—
if it can be covered by the ancient [ritual],
then its spirit is set on domestication—
this is the path of humiliation.

The reason honor becomes humiliation
is thus.

Therefore, the ancients who excelled in *shi*’s way:
The rank of three *jīng* flags was insufficient to shake their resolve,
for they knew that what lies within me
is nobler than the rank of three *jīng* flags.
The wealth of ten thousand *chóng* measures could not shift their steadfastness,
for they knew that what lies within me
is richer than ten thousand *chóng* measures.

To master the art of retaining favor,
one dwells in favor yet ponders peril;
to grasp the way of preserving fortune,
one holds fortune yet acts as though empty—
thus, they can endure wealth and rank without losing themselves,
and their blessings and fortunes endure long and steady.
What humiliation could there be?

If one covets rank yet falsifies oneself to gain nobility,
or craves wealth yet indulges in corruption to gain riches,
knowing advancement yet not retreat,
obscuring the logic of growth and decline,
grasping gain yet not foreseeing loss,
ignoring the cycles of fullness and emptiness—
then the nobility of *Zhao Meng*
is but a step toward debasement.

Thus, to receive favor from others
is the way of the lowly.

To gain it is like a startling fright,
to lose it is like a startling fright—
this is *"honor and humiliation are like a startling fright"*.

*Huizong*’s annotation says:
The cap and robes upon one’s person
are not the Dao/Way of life and death.
External things arrive like transient guests—
if they come, they cannot be refused;
thus, the sage does not take delight in gaining them.
If they depart, they cannot be detained—
thus, the sage does not sorrow over losing them.
Yet now, if they depart, one finds no joy,
and if received, one takes pleasure—
so gain and loss burden the heart,
how could one not be startled?

*Liu Xià Huì* served as a magistrate,
thrice dismissed yet refusing to leave,
*Zhèng Kǎo Fù* received three commands,
yet fled along the walls—
how different from this!

The *Shūyì* elaborates:
True nobility lies within oneself—
enough to rival the titles of a kingdom.
Yet the cap and robes upon one’s person
are not the Dao/Way of life and death.
External things cannot be clung to,
and seeking them brings no benefit to what is already gained—
for they arrive like transient guests.
Only time is without end,
so their coming cannot be refused,
and their gain—
what does it add to me?
Thus, the sage does not take delight in gaining them.

Only division is without permanence,
so their departure cannot be detained—
and their loss—
what harm does it bring to me?
Thus, the sage does not sorrow over losing them.
The deluded do not understand the extremes of destitution and abundance,
like the sequence of winter and summer—
if they depart, one finds no joy,
or one may fall into poverty and lowliness.
If received, one takes pleasure,
or one may be bent by wealth and rank.
Gain and loss wage war within the chest,
even the spirit platform is obstructed—
how few escape being startled!

*Liu Xià Huì* served as a magistrate,
thrice dismissed yet refusing to leave,
*Zhèng Kǎo Fù* received three commands,
yet fled along the walls—
could it be that gain and loss burdened their hearts?
What is meant by *"the greatest calamity of nobility is like the body"*?

*Huizong*’s annotation says:
To grasp advantage and power,
to monopolize rewards and punishments,
to wield blessings and threats—
the world fears them like gods and reveres them like emperors.
This is nobility indeed.

Yet the sage does not let nobility weigh upon them,
so they can long endure nobility without exhaustion.
Like a person whose limbs and body fall into ruin,
whose ears and eyes lose their acuity,
who abandons form yet is not bound by it,
who discards wisdom yet does not cling to it—
to merge with the Great Unity,
then there is none who does not find themselves at ease.
The world’s people exchange their nature for things,
so they are burdened by things yet cannot forget their power.
They let form weigh upon the heart,
so they lose the heart yet cannot forget form—
their calamity is great.

The *Shūyì* elaborates:
To dwell in nobility as one’s own,
one cannot escape exhaustion—
only if one does not claim nobility as one’s own
can one truly guard it.
Like a person’s body:
to think it is mine brings constant hindrance;
to know the body is not truly mine,
then one can preserve it.

Now, if one grasps the weight of advantage and power,
holds the authority of rewards and punishments,
and monopolizes the tools of blessings and threats—
the world fears them like gods and reveres them like emperors,
their nobility is unmatched.
Yet only the sage, wielding the void to govern the full,
does not dwell in nobility as their own—
so though they are noble, they suffer no exhaustion.

Like a person’s body:
to contain the hundred bones yet let limbs falter,
to embody ears and eyes yet let wisdom dim,
to abandon form yet not be constrained by it,
to discard wisdom yet not cling to it—
then one attains Great Permeation,
constructing the formless,
and there is none who does not find themselves at ease.
Who could take the body as exhaustion?

The vulgar and shallow cannot exhaust their nature while fixating on power,
so they are burdened by things, exchanging their nature for them;
they cannot exhaust their heart while clinging to form,
so they are weighed down by form, losing their heart.
To exchange one’s nature for things,
to let form weigh upon the heart—
their calamity is great.

The reason I have great calamity
is that I have a body.
When I have no body,
what calamity could I have?

*Huizong*’s annotation says:
Human birth—
the hundred bones, nine orifices, six viscera are complete and stored within.
Who could I truly call my own?
To recognize and claim them all
is but delusion.
Those who embody the Dao understand this,
so Confucius said:
*"Morning hearing of the Dao,
evening death would be acceptable."*
Mencius said:
*"Life and death are not two separate things."*
Yan Ziyuan said:
*"Yan [Child] sat and forgot himself."*」

chunks.original_text: 夫死生亦大矣，而无变于己，况得丧祸福之所介乎？ 此古之至人所以不以利累形，不以形累心。 视万物与我将择焉而不可得，则吾身非吾有也。 上与造物者游，下与外死生无终始者为友，吾有何息？ 且宠者世所荣也，而以为辱，贵者人所乐也，而以为息，盖外物之不可恃也，理固然矣。 诚能有之以无有j 则虽宠而不辱，虽贵而无息。 伊尹之不以宠利居成功，尧之不以位为乐，几是已。 疏义曰：形骸之内有真君，足以高天下； 有真宰，足以制万物。 形骸之外，百骸九窍六脏赅而存焉，吾谁与为亲？ 苟不知索於形体之内，方且本身而异形，认而有之，皆感也。 惟体道者知形形之不形，虽其形化，而吾有不忘者存。 故朝闻道，夕死可矣。 孟子曰：夭寿不二。 齐寿夭也。 颜子曰：回坐忘矣。 忘物我也。 夫死生亦大矣，而无变于己，况得丧祸福之所介乎？ 此无他，知形骸之内有真君真宰者存，故总括百骸者，不能为之患也。 古之至人不以利累形，异乎见得而忘形； 不以形累心，至於废心而用形。 内观其心，心无其心，外观其形，形无其形，远观其物，物无其物，视万物与我将择焉而不得，则吾身非吾有也。 见不见之形，上与造物者游，下与外死生无终始者为友，夫孰足以息？ 心已是则虽宠而不辱，虽贵而无息，岂以世之所荣而为辱，人之所乐而为息哉？ 伊尹不以宠利居成功而得持宠之术，尧不以位为乐而得守贵之道，几是已。 故贵以身为天下，若可寄天下； 爱以身为天下，若可托天下。 徽宗注曰：天下大器也，非道莫运； 天下神器也，非道莫守。 圣人体道，故在宥天下，天下乐推而不厌。 其次则知贵其身而不自贱以役於物者，若可寄而已； 知爱其身而不自贼以困於物者，若可托而已。 故曰道之真以治身，绪余以为国家，土直以治天下。 世俗之君子，乃危身弃生以殉物，岂不悲夫？ 疏义曰：六合内外，无尽无极，则天下大器也。 必有出乎器者，然后能运之，出乎器者，道也。 立乎不测，行乎无方，则天下神器也。 必有与於神者，然后能守之，与於神者，道也。 圣人体是以在己，故在天下而不淫其性，宥天下而不迁其德，自西自东，自南自北，无思不服，天下乐推而不厌矣。 其次则有明乎物物之非物，而无以天下为者，知一节重於一国，两臂重於天下，身亦重於两臂，贵其身而不自贼，爱其身而不自贱，若可寄托而已。 夫岂残生伤性，以身为殉，樊然殽乱为物所役，薾然疲役为物所困，不知保身之道欤？ 庄子所谓道之真以治身，绪余以为国家，土直以治天下，正谓是也。 世俗之君子不知身为生之主，乃杀身以成名，多方以丧生，逐物而不返，危身弃生以徇物，是犹以隋侯之珠弹千仞之雀，所丧多矣，岂不悲夫。 视之不见章第十四 视之不见名曰夷， 徽宗注曰：目主视，视以辩物，夷则平而无辩，非视所及，故名曰夷。 太易未见，气是已。 疏义曰：天三生木，在人为肝，肝开窍於目，故於五事为视，则目主视故也。 明两作离＃２，寓象於目，而目之於色，合而后有见，则视以辫物故也。 然视而可见，未离乎色，或高或下，可得而辩也。 妙道非色，青然空然，曾无兆朕，视之不足见也。 其平坦然，孰辩高下？
chunks.translated_text:
The greatness of life and death is vast indeed,
yet it does not alter one’s self—
how much more so the gains and losses, calamities and blessings, that lie between them?

This has no other cause
than knowing that within one’s form and body dwell the true *Dao/Way* and sovereign.
Thus, the *Zhi Ren* of antiquity
did not let profit weigh upon their form,
nor did their form weigh upon their heart.
They saw all things as inseparable from themselves,
yet could not choose among them—
then their body was not truly theirs.

Above, they played with the *造物者* [Creator],
below, they befriended the external, endless life and death.
Who could truly weary them?
Favored by the world, yet they took it as dishonor;
held in esteem by all, yet they saw it as no burden—
for they knew the external things could not be relied upon,
and this was the natural order.

If one can truly possess without possessing,
then though favored, they would not be shamed,
though esteemed, they would not be weary.
Yi Yin did not dwell on favor and success,
while Yao did not take his position as pleasure—
this is nearly it.

*Huizong*’s annotation says:
The world is a great vessel,
but only the *Dao/Way* can move it;
the world is a divine vessel,
but only the *Dao/Way* can guard it.
The sage embodies the *Dao/Way*,
so when they govern the world, the world finds joy in their benevolence without tiring.
The lesser ones know that to value their body is not to demean themselves in serving things,
as though they could entrust it—
to love their body is not to harm themselves in being constrained by things,
as though they could rely upon it.

Thus it is said:
The true *Dao/Way* is used to govern oneself,
its remnants to govern the state,
and its dregs to govern the world.
The vulgar *junzi* of the world
endanger their body and abandon their life to serve things—
is this not tragic?

The *Shu Yi* says:
Within the six directions and beyond,
there is no end or limit—
the world is a great vessel.
There must be what transcends the vessel
before it can be moved—
what transcends the vessel is the *Dao/Way*.
Established in the unfathomable,
acting without fixed methods—
the world is a divine vessel.
There must be what aligns with the divine
before it can be guarded—
what aligns with the divine is the *Dao/Way*.
The sage embodies this within themselves,
so they govern the world without corrupting their nature,
bear the world’s burdens without altering their *virtue/power*,
and from west to east, from south to north,
none do not submit—
the world finds joy in their benevolence without tiring.

The lesser ones understand that things are not truly things,
yet they do not know how to govern the world.
They know that one limb is heavier than one kingdom,
two arms are heavier than the world,
and the body is heavier than two arms—
to value their body is not to harm themselves,
to love their body is not to demean themselves—
as though they could entrust and rely upon it.

Is it not that they mutilate life and harm their nature,
sacrificing their body—
restlessly enslaved by things,
wearily burdened by things,
not knowing the way to preserve themselves?

This is exactly what Zhuangzi meant by:
The true *Dao/Way* is used to govern oneself,
its remnants to govern the state,
and its dregs to govern the world.

The vulgar *junzi* of the world do not know that the body is the master of life,
so they kill their body to achieve fame,
use many means to destroy their life,
chase after things without returning—
endangering their body and abandoning their life to follow things,
like using the *Su Hou’s pearl* to shoot a thousand *ren*-high sparrow,
losing far more than they gain—
is this not tragic?

**Chapter 14: The Vision That Does Not See Forms**
The vision that does not see forms is called *yi* [level/plain].

*Huizong*’s annotation says:
The eyes are the master of vision,
vision is used to distinguish things—
*yi* is level and without distinction,
not within the reach of vision,
so it is called *yi*.

The *Tai Yi* [Great Oneness] is unseen,
yet *qi* is already there.

The *Shu Yi* says:
Heaven gives birth to wood in threes,
which in humans becomes the liver—
the liver opens to the eyes,
so in the five *zang* organs, it governs vision.
Thus the eyes are the master of vision.

The *ming liang* [clear vision] is *li* [separation] in two,
symbolized in the eyes,
and the eyes, regarding colors,
unite only after seeing—
thus vision is used to distinguish things.

Yet when vision can see,
it has not yet separated from colors—
whether high or low,
it can be distinguished.
The wondrous *Dao/Way* is not a color—
green and empty, void and empty,
not the slightest trace or sign—
vision is insufficient to see it.
Its level and boundless nature—
who could distinguish high from low?

chunks.original_text: 列子所谓太易未见，气是已。 浑沦之初，气且未见，其平可知，故名曰夷。 听之不闻名曰希， 徽宗注曰：耳主听，听以察物，希则穊而有间，非听所闻，故名曰希。 大音希声是已。 疏义曰：天一生水，在藏为肾，肾开窍於耳，故於五事为听，则耳主听也。 水荐至为坎，寓象於耳，而耳之於声，辫而后能听，则听以察物故也。 然听而可闻，未离乎声，迭为清浊，莫之能间。 妙道无声，寂兮寥兮，曾无音响，听之不足闻也。 风济籁息，概而有间，经所谓大音希声是已。 动於无方，居於窈冥，其穊可知，故名曰希。 搏之不得名曰微。 徽宗注曰：微乎微乎，至於无形，孰得而搏之？ 大象无形是已。 疏义曰：气变而后有形，有形而后可得。 至道之精，窈窈冥冥，未始有物，循之而不得也，是谓微乎微乎，至於无形者矣。 有形斯可搏，道之无形，孰得而搏之？ 经所谓大象无形，则象之大者，孰有过於道者哉？ 夫惟无形，故其大无外也。 此三者不可致诂，故混而为一。 徽宗注曰：太易未判，孰分高下？ 大音希声，孰辫清浊？ 大象无形，孰为巨细？
chunks.translated_text:
The *Liezi* states: *The Tai Yi* [Great Oneness] is unseen, yet *qi* is already there.

In the beginning of *hunlun* [chaotic unity], *qi* has not yet manifested, its level and boundless nature is known, hence it is called *yi* [evenness].

When hearing does not hear, it is called *xi* [subtle/rare].

The *Huizong* [Emperor Huizong] annotated: The ears govern hearing, and hearing is used to discern things. *Xi* [subtle/rare] implies a faintness with gaps, beyond what hearing can perceive—hence it is called *xi*.

*The great sound, rare and faint, is already there.*

The *Shu Yi* [loose exposition] says:
Heaven one gives birth to water,
in the *zang* [viscera] it becomes the kidneys—
the kidneys open to the ears,
so in the five *zang* organs, it governs hearing,
and thus the ears are the master of hearing.

Water reaching its extreme becomes *kan* [the abyss],
symbolized in the ears,
and the ears, regarding sounds,
distinguish them only after perception—
thus hearing is used to discern things.

Yet when hearing can perceive,
it has not yet separated from sounds—
whether clear or murky,
none can distinguish them.

The wondrous *Dao/Way* has no sound—
still and vast, *leao* [silent and empty],
never the slightest echo or resonance,
hearing is insufficient to perceive it.

The wind ceases, the rustling subsides,
faint and with gaps—
the *jing* [classic] says: *The great sound, rare and faint, is already there.*

It moves without direction,
dwells in the *yaoming* [profoundly obscure],
its faintness is known—
hence it is called *xi*.

When it cannot be grasped, it is called *wei* [minute].

The *Huizong* annotated: *Minute, how minute!*—
reaching the point of formlessness,
who could grasp it?

*The great form is formless, is already there.*

The *Shu Yi* says:
When *qi* transforms, only then does form arise,
and when form arises, it can be perceived.

The essence of the *Dao/Way* is profoundly obscure—
before anything began,
following it, yet unable to grasp it—
this is called *minute, how minute!*
reaching the point of formlessness.

When form exists, it can be grasped,
but the *Dao/Way*’s formlessness—
who could grasp it?

The *jing* [classic] says: *The great form is formless*—
then what form is greater than the *Dao/Way*?

It is only because it is formless,
that its greatness knows no bounds.

These three cannot be defined with precision—
hence they merge into one.

The *Huizong* annotated:
*The Tai Yi* [Great Oneness] is undifferentiated—
who could distinguish high from low?

*The great sound, rare and faint*—
who could discern clear from murky?

*The great form is formless*—
who could define vast from minute?

chunks.original_text: 目无所用其明，耳无所施其聪，形无所竭其力，道之全体於是乎在。 穷之不可究，探之不可得也。 气形质具而未相离，故混而为一。 虽然，既已为一矣，且得无言乎？ 疏义曰：太易未判，列子所谓色色者未尝呈是也。 色色者无色，孰分高下？ 大音希声，列子所谓声声者未尝发是也。 声声者无声，孰辫清浊？ 大象无形，列子所谓形形者未尝显是也。 形形者无形，孰为巨细？ 虽使离朱当昼拭訾望之而不见其形，则目无所用其明也。 虽使师旷终夜俛首倾耳而听之不闻其声，则耳无所施其聪也。 虽使知与吃诟之徒索之而终莫得，则形无所竭其力也。 自其视之不见，言之则曰夷。 自其听之不闻，言之则曰希。 自其搏之不得，言之则曰微。 三者异名同实，其指一也，道之全体於是乎在。 穷之不可究，探之不可得，列子所谓浑沦是也。 谓之浑沦，则以气形质具混为一，而未相离故也。 既已为一矣，且得无言乎？ 其上不皦，其下不昧。 徽宗注曰：形而上者，阴阳不测，幽而难无，兹谓至神，故不皦。 皦言明也。 形而下者，一阴一阳，辫而有数，兹谓至道，故不昧。 昧言幽也。 《易》曰：神而明之，存乎其人。 疏义曰：形而上者谓之道，而神实妙焉，则神固形而上矣。 阴知神之在阴，而不知其亦在阳，阳知神之在阳，而不知其亦在阴，神则阴阳不测也。 速不疾而行不至，惛然若亡而存，是之谓其上不皦。 形而下者谓. 之器，而道实寓焉，则道亦形而下矣。 不偏于阳，非独阳而生，不毗于阴，非独阴而成，道则一阴一阳也。 可以约，可以散，在无亦显，是之谓其下不昧。 盖皦与皦如之皦同，皦言明也，不皦则幽而难知矣。 昧与昧谷之昧同，昧言幽也，不昧则辫而有数矣。 虽然，苟非其人，道不虚行，则神而明之，存乎其人故也。 绳绳兮不可名，复归於无物。 徽宗注曰：道之体，若昼夜之有经，而莫测其幽明之故，岂貌像声色可得而形容乎？ 故复归於无物。 疏义曰：绳以约物，使不失其直，绳绳则不出乎防范检押之内也。 道之伦经，有条而不紊，若昼夜之有经，一晦一明无或渝也，故谓之绳绳。 然深妙眇冥，无有无名，莫测其幽明之故，是以不可名。 若然则复本归根，一毫不留，非特未始有物，而又至於未始有夫未始有物者矣，岂貌像声色可得而形容乎？ 是之谓复归於无物。 是谓无状之状，无物之象，是谓恍惚。 徽宗注曰：无状之状，无物之象，恍兮惚，其中有物，惚兮恍，其中有象。 犹如太虚含蓄万象，而不诸其端倪。 犹如一性灵智自若，而莫究其运用。 谓之有而非有，谓之无而非无，若日月之去人远矣，以鉴燧求焉，而水火自至。 水火果何在哉？ 无状之状，无物之象，亦犹是也。 疏义曰：有状故可见，道无见也，亦不离见，故为无状之状。 有形故可象，道无形也，亦不离形，故为无物之象。 无状之状，无物之象，意其有而非有，恍兮惚而中有物也，意其无而非无，惚兮恍而中有象也，如太虚一虚化出万有而未始有封，含蓄万象不睹其端倪也。 如一性无性，应物不穷而深不可测，灵智自若而莫究其妙用也。 即有而无，有实非有，即无而有，无实非无。 若日月去人远矣，以方诸取水於月，以阳燧取火於日，不旋顷而水火自至。
chunks.translated_text:
The eyes have no use for their brightness,
the ears no application for their sharpness,
the body no exertion for its strength—
here lies the *Dao/Way*'s complete essence.

It cannot be exhausted by inquiry,
nor attained by exploration.

When *qi*, form, and substance are present yet undivided,
thus they merge into one.

Yet once they have become one,
how could it not be called *formless*?

The *Cushui* [commentary] says:
*The Tai Yi* [Great Oneness] is yet unjudged—
the *Liezi*’s "color-color" never reveals this.
"Color-color" is without color,
how could it distinguish high from low?

*The great sound is faint*—
the *Liezi*’s "sound-sound" never emits this.
"Sound-sound" is without sound,
how could it discern clear from murky?

*The great form is formless*—
the *Liezi*’s "shape-shape" never displays this.
"Shape-shape" is without form,
how could it define vast from minute?

Even if *Lizhu* [legendary seer] were to polish his eyes at noon and gaze,
he would still not perceive its form—
thus the eyes have no use for their brightness.

Even if *Shigang* [master of hearing] were to bow his head all night and strain his ears,
he would still not hear its sound—
thus the ears have no application for their sharpness.

Even if the wisest and most voracious scholars were to search endlessly,
they would never attain it—
thus the body has no exertion for its strength.

From its unseen aspect, it is called *formless*;
from its unheard aspect, it is called *faint*;
from its untouchable aspect, it is called *minute*.

These three share the same essence though different names,
pointing to one reality—
here lies the *Dao/Way*'s complete essence.

It cannot be exhausted by inquiry,
nor attained by exploration—
this is the *Liezi*’s "indistinct and chaotic."

Called "indistinct and chaotic,"
it is because *qi*, form, and substance are present yet undivided,
and they have not yet separated.

Once they have become one,
how could it not be called *formless*?

Its uppermost aspect is not *illuminated*,
its lowermost aspect is not *obscured*.

The *Huizong* annotated:
That which is beyond form—
the inscrutable interplay of *yin* and *yang*,
dark yet not easily lost—
this is called *ultimate mystery*, hence not *illuminated*.
"Illuminated" means "bright," and not *illuminated* means profound and difficult to know.

That which is beneath form—
one *yin*, one *yang*,
distinct yet numbered—
this is called *ultimate Dao/Way*, hence not *obscured*.
"Obscured" means "dark," and not *obscured* means clear and discernible.

The *Yijing* [Classic of Changes] says:
*The mysterious and the bright*—
this depends on the person.

The *Cushui* [commentary] says:
That which is beyond form is called *Dao/Way*,
and the mysterious is indeed its marvel.
Thus the mysterious is inherently beyond form.

*Yin* knows the mysterious exists within *yin*,
yet does not know it also exists within *yang*;
*Yang* knows the mysterious exists within *yang*,
yet does not know it also exists within *yin*.
Hence the mysterious is inscrutable in *yin* and *yang*.

Swift yet not hasty, moving yet not arriving,
lost yet truly present—
this is called the uppermost not *illuminated*.

That which is beneath form is called *instrumentality*,
yet the *Dao/Way* truly resides within it—
thus the *Dao/Way* is also beneath form.

It does not lean toward *yang* alone,
nor is it born solely from *yang*;
it does not cling to *yin* alone,
nor is it formed solely from *yin*.
Hence the *Dao/Way* is one *yin* and one *yang*.

It can be confined, it can be dispersed,
in the void yet manifest—
this is called the lowermost not *obscured*.

For "illuminated" and "illuminated" are as the same,
"illuminated" meaning "bright"—
not *illuminated* means profound and difficult to know.

For "obscured" and "obscured" are as the same,
"obscured" meaning "dark"—
not *obscured* means clear and discernible.

Yet if not the person,
the *Dao/Way* does not act in vain—
thus it is said: *The mysterious and the bright*—
this depends on the person.

Boundless yet nameless,
it returns to *non-existence*.

The *Huizong* annotated:
The *Dao/Way*'s essence—
like the regular succession of day and night,
yet its profound and bright nature is unfathomable.
Could it be captured in appearance, sound, or color?
Hence it returns to *non-existence*.

The *Cushui* [commentary] says:
The *Dao/Way*’s *thread*—
like the measure of things,
ensuring nothing strays from its straightness.
"Boundless" means it does not exceed the limits of regulation and scrutiny.

The *Dao/Way*'s *pattern* is orderly yet not disordered,
like the regular succession of day and night—
one dark, one bright, never failing.
Hence it is called "boundless."

Yet profound and marvelously obscure,
it has no name, no nameable origin,
and its profound and bright nature is unfathomable—
thus it cannot be named.

If so, then it returns to its root,
leaving not even a trace,
not only *non-existence* at the beginning,
but also *non-existence* beyond the beginning of *non-existence*—
how could it be captured in appearance, sound, or color?
This is called returning to *non-existence*.

This is called *the state of the stateless*,
the *form of the formless*—
this is called *dimly discernible*.

The *Huizong* annotated:
*The state of the stateless*,
the *form of the formless*—
dimly discernible, yet within it is substance;
obscure, yet within it are forms.

Like the *Great Void* [Tai Xu] containing all forms,
yet not revealing their outlines.

Like one *nature* [xing], one *spiritual intelligence* [lingzhi],
self-sufficient yet unfathomable in its workings.

Called "having yet not having,"
called "not having yet having"—
like the sun and moon, though distant,
when seeking water in their reflection or fire in their rays,
the water and fire arrive without delay.

Where do the water and fire truly reside?
*The state of the stateless*,
the *form of the formless*—
this is the same.

The *Cushui* [commentary] says:
There is a state, hence it can be seen,
yet the *Dao/Way* is unseen—
also not separate from seeing—
thus it is the *state of the stateless*.

There is a form, hence it can be represented,
yet the *Dao/Way* is formless—
also not separate from form—
thus it is the *form of the formless*.

*The state of the stateless*,
the *form of the formless*—
it suggests "having yet not having,"
dimly discernible yet containing substance,
it suggests "not having yet not having,"
obscure yet containing forms—
like the *Great Void* [Tai Xu],
one void giving rise to all things,
yet never confined,
containing all forms without revealing their outlines.

Like one *nature* [xing] without *nature*,
responding to all things without end,
deep yet unfathomable,
spiritual intelligence self-sufficient,
yet its marvelous workings are unfathomable.

It is having yet not having,
having in reality yet not having;
it is not having yet having,
not having in reality yet having.

As when the sun and moon are distant from people,
yet seeking water in the moon’s reflection
or fire in the sun’s rays with a *square mirror* [fangzhu] or *sunburner* [yangsui],
the water and fire arrive in no time.

chunks.original_text: 水火之为物，不可以有无期之也，无状之状，无物之象，亦犹是也，故谓之恍惚。 迎之不见其首，随之不见其后。 徽宗注曰：其始无首，其卒无尾，故迎之随之，有不得而见焉。 疏义曰：道之全体，混成完具，赡之在前，孰原其所始？ 忽焉在后，孰要其所终？ 庄子所谓其始无首，其卒无尾是也。 迎之随之，曾何有见哉？ 执古之道，以御今之有。 能知古始，是谓道纪。 徽宗注曰：一阴一阳之谓道。 师天而无地者，或蔽于道之动而凭其强阳； 师阴而无阳者，或溺于道之静而止於桔槁。 为我者废七，为人者废义，岂古之道哉？ 古之道不可致诂而非有，是谓恍惚而非无。 执之以御世，则变通以尽利，鼓舞以尽神，而无不可者，道之大常无易于此，所谓自古以固存者欤？ 故曰能知古始，是谓道纪。 疏义曰：立天之道曰阴与阳，则道虽非阴阳，亦不离阴阳故也。 昧於道者分阴分阳，或悦生而累形，则蔽于道之动而凭其强阳； 或趋寂以忘身，则溺於道之静而止乎桔槁。 为墨氏之兼爱者，为人而废义，至於无见於畸。 为杨氏之为我者，为我而废仁，至於荡而不法不该不偏，蔽於一曲。 岂古之道哉？ 古之道有不废无，不可致诂而非有，无不外有，是谓恍惚而非无。 操此为验，稽此为次，以应万变，以对方来，变通足以尽利，鼓舞足以尽神，其於御世，无不可者，此古之道也。 是道也，长於上古而不为老，未有天地，自古以固存。 维纲宰制，凡囿於物，未有外是而能立者，道之大常无易于此。 惟能探物之先而知其始，则道之伦经皆在我矣，故曰是谓道纪。 道德真经疏义卷之三竟 ＃１则与化为：『 为』 后疑脱『 一』。 ＃２明两作离：『  离』前疑脱『 为』 。 道德真经疏义卷之四 太学生江澄疏
chunks.translated_text:
「Water and fire, as things,
cannot be confined by the limits of having or not having.
Without form yet possessing form,
without substance yet containing essence—
this too is the case,
hence it is called *dimly discernible* [huánghū].

Approach it and you do not see its beginning,
follow it and you do not see its end.
Emperor *Huizong*’s annotation states:
*"Its beginning lacks a head,
its conclusion lacks a tail;
thus, when one approaches or follows it,
there is something one cannot fully perceive."*

The *Explanatory Commentary* says:
*"The complete body of the Dao
is a harmonious unity, whole and perfect.
When it precedes all things,
who can trace its origin?
When it suddenly appears,
who can grasp its conclusion?
This is what Zhuangzi meant by
its beginning lacking a head,
its conclusion lacking a tail.
Approach or follow it—
how could one ever truly see it?"*

To uphold the Dao of antiquity
and govern the present’s existence—
one who knows the ancient origins
is called *Dao’s fundamental principle* [dàojì].

Emperor *Huizong*’s annotation states:
*"One yin and one yang—this is the Dao."*

Those who follow Heaven’s Dao without Earth’s
may be blinded by its dynamism,
leaning upon its overwhelming yang—
those who follow Earth’s Dao without Heaven’s
may be drowned in its stillness,
halting at withered decay.

The *Moists*, who embrace universal love,
prioritize others while abandoning *rightness* [yì],
reaching a point where they see no extremes.
The *Yangists*, who uphold self-interest,
abandon *benevolence* [rén],
swinging wildly without law, without balance, without deviation—
they are confined by one-sidedness.
Is this the Dao of antiquity?

The Dao of antiquity
cannot be exhaustively defined yet is not nonexistent—
it is *dimly discernible* yet not *non-existent*.
Nothing exists outside its embrace,
thus it is called *dimly discernible* yet not *non-existent*.

To wield it for practical effect,
to examine it for validation—
to respond to all transformations,
to meet all that comes—
its adaptability is sufficient to exhaust all benefits,
its vitality is sufficient to exhaust all spiritual potency,
and in governing the world,
there is nothing it cannot address.
This is the Dao’s enduring constancy,
unchanging from ancient times—
the Dao that has always existed since before Heaven and Earth.

It is the *pivotal axis* [gāngzǎi] that governs all.
All who are bound by things,
without transcending this truth,
cannot stand firm.
The Dao’s enduring constancy knows no change.

Only those who can probe
the origins of all things
and know their beginnings
hold within themselves
the * Dao’s fundamental principles* [lúnjīng].
Thus it is said:
*"This is called Dao’s fundamental principle."* [dàojì]

The *Explanatory Commentary* on the *True Classic of Dao and Virtue* concludes:

*"The Dao of Heaven is established as yin and yang,
yet though the Dao is not yin and yang,
it never departs from them.
Those who are ignorant of the Dao
split it into yin and yang alone—
some delight in life and burden the form,
thus blinded by the Dao’s dynamism,
leaning upon its overwhelming yang;
others pursue emptiness and forget the body,
thus drowned in the Dao’s stillness,
halting at withered decay.

The *Moists*, who embrace universal love,
prioritize others while abandoning *rightness* [yì],
reaching a point where they see no extremes—
this is their deviation.

The *Yangists*, who uphold self-interest,
abandon *benevolence* [rén],
swinging wildly without law, without balance, without deviation—
they are confined by one-sidedness.
Is this the Dao of antiquity?

The Dao of antiquity
has neither what is discarded nor what is retained—
it cannot be exhaustively defined yet is not nonexistent,
and nothing exists outside its embrace.
Thus it is called *dimly discernible* yet not *non-existent*.

To wield it for practical effect,
to examine it for validation—
to respond to all transformations,
to meet all that comes—
its adaptability is sufficient to exhaust all benefits,
its vitality is sufficient to exhaust all spiritual potency,
and in governing the world,
there is nothing it cannot address.
This is the Dao of antiquity.

This Dao,
long before the Upper Antiquity,
was not yet old—
before Heaven and Earth existed,
it had always been preserved.
It is the *pivotal axis* [gāngzǎi] that governs all.
All who are bound by things,
without transcending this truth,
cannot stand firm.
The Dao’s enduring constancy knows no change.

Only those who can probe
the origins of all things
and know their beginnings
hold within themselves
the * Dao’s fundamental principles* [lúnjīng].
Thus it is said:
*"This is called Dao’s fundamental principle."* [dàojì]

End of Volume Three of the *Explanatory Commentary* on the *True Classic of Dao and Virtue*.

#1 The text likely omits 『一』 after 『为』 in *"To wield it for practical effect"* (操此为验).
#2 The original likely has 『离』 after 『明两作』, with 『为』 omitted before it (明两为离).」

chunks.original_text: 古之善为士章第十五 古之善为士者，微妙玄通，深不可识。 徽宗注曰：古之士则与今之士异矣，善为士则与不善为士者异矣。 故微则与道为一，妙则与神同体，玄有以配天，通有以兆圣，而藏用之深，至於不可测。 《书》曰：道心惟．微。 则微者，道也。 《易》曰：神也者，妙万物而为言。 则妙者，神也。 《易》曰：天玄而地黄。 则玄者，天之色。 《传》曰：事无不通之谓圣。 则通者，圣之事。 水之深者可测也，穴之深者可究也。 古之善为士者，微妙玄通，名实不入而机发於踵，其藏深矣，不可测究。 列御寇居郑圃四十年，人无识者。 老子谓孔子曰：良贾深藏若虚，君子盛德，容貌若愚。 其谓是欤？ 疏义曰：有上古，有中古，古之士则上古之士也。 有上士，有下士，善为士则上士之类也。 则古之士与今之士异矣，善为士与不善为士异矣。 善为士者，其才上达，志於道而与乎神，明於天而通於圣，渊乎其不可测，故微妙玄通，深不可识。 盖视之不见名曰微，道无形也，不可以目视，惟知微，故与道为一。 《书》所谓道心惟微是也。 常无欲以观其妙，神无是也，不可以有求，惟入妙，故与神同体。 《易》所谓神妙万物而为言是也。 玄之为色，有赤有炁，以能阴能阳故也，而、天之色在是焉。 《易》所谓天玄而地黄者，以此。 能玄能黄，则与天为徒矣。 通之为义，往来不穷，以无物能碍故也，而圣之事在是焉。 《传》所谓事无本通之谓圣者，以此。 同於大通，则入自圣门矣。 古之善为士者，自微妙以至玄通，奭然四解，沦於不测，非若水之深可测，穴之深可究。 杜德机而不示，丰智源而音出，名实不入而机发於肿。 若火事已而见灰，其藏深矣，不可测究，世何足以识之？ 昔列御寇居郑圃四十年，人无识者，得此故也。 盍圃泽多贤，里非无仁也，历年四十，处非不久也，而人无识之者，则以图滑疑之耀，去形谋之光，人无得而识之也。 孟子所谓君子之所为，众人固不识谓是。 故尔。 老子谓孔子曰：良贾深藏若虚，君子盛德，容貌若愚。 则以盛德若不足，犹之良贾可也。 此颜子如愚，孔子贤之。 夫惟不可识，故强为之容： 徽宗注曰：天之高，不可俄而度也； 地之厚，不可俄而测也。 曰圆以覆，曰方以载者，拟诸其容而已。 强为之容，岂能真索其至？ 疏义曰：天统元气，非止荡荡苍苍之谓也，故其高不可俄而度。 地统元形，非止山林川泽之谓也，故其厚不可俄而测。 穹窿乎上人，谓其圆以覆。 磅砖乎下人，谓其方以载。 特拟诸容而强名之尔。 善为士者，微妙玄通，深不可识，亦天地已。 如下文所云，皆强为之容而已。 豫兮若冬涉川，犹兮若畏四邻。 徽宗注曰：豫者，图息於未然。 犹者，致疑於已事。 古之体道者，以内游为务，不以通物为乐，恐惧修省，不得已而后应，若冬涉川，守而不失已。 若畏四邻，《易》所谓以此斋戒者是也。 疏义曰：先事而图谓之豫，则豫者图息於未然。 后事而图谓之犹，则犹者致疑於已事。 古之体道者，以内游为务，不以外游为至，以忘物为善，不以通物为乐，恐惧修省，不敢肆也。 故於事之未至者，感而后应，迫而后动，不得已而后起，先事而图，如冬涉川。
chunks.translated_text:
Chapter Fifteen: The Mastery of the *Dao’s Virtuous Way* [Shànwéi Shì Zhāng] of Antiquity

The ancient masters of the *Dao’s Virtuous Way* [shànwéi shì] were subtle, wondrous, and profound—so deep as to be unrecognizable.
The Emperor Huizong’s annotation states: The ancient *Dao’s Virtuous Way* [shì] differed from that of today, and the masters who excelled in it differed from those who did not.
Thus, subtlety [wēi] aligns with the Dao, wondrousness [miào] harmonizes with the *Divine* [shén], profundity [yuān] matches the heavens, and penetration [tōng] reveals the *Sage’s* [shèng] essence. Yet, their depths are so concealed that they cannot be measured.

The *Book of Documents* [Shū] says: *"The Dao’s heart is but subtle."* [dàoxīn wéi wēi]
Thus, subtlety [wēi] is the Dao itself.
The *Book of Changes* [Yì] says: *"The Divine, indeed, is wondrous in all things and is named thus."* [shén yě zhě miào wànwù ér wéi yán]
Thus, wondrousness [miào] is the Divine.
The *Book of Changes* says: *"The heavens are profound, and the earth is vast."* [tiān xuán ér dì huáng]
Thus, profundity [yuān] is the color of the heavens.
The *Commentary* [Zhuàn] says: *"There is no obstruction in all things—this is called the Sage."* [shì wú bù tōng zhī wéi shèng]
Thus, penetration [tōng] is the Sage’s work.
The depths of water can be measured, and the depths of pits can be explored.
Yet the ancient masters of the *Dao’s Virtuous Way* [shànwéi shì], their names and deeds unseen, awaken responses from the heels—so profound that they cannot be measured or explored.
Lü Yu was in Zhengpu for forty years, yet no one recognized him.
Laozi spoke to Confucius: *"A fine merchant hides his wares as if they were none; a Sage of virtue, though full of power, appears as if foolish."*
Is this what he meant?

The *Explanatory Commentary* [Shūyì] states: There was the Upper Antiquity, and the Middle Antiquity; the ancient *Dao’s Virtuous Way* [shì] refers to the Upper Antiquity.
There were the Upper Masters [shàngshì] and the Lower Masters [xiàshì]; the masters who excelled in the *Dao’s Virtuous Way* [shànwéi shì] were of the Upper Master class.
Thus, the ancient *Dao’s Virtuous Way* [shì] differed from that of today, and the masters who excelled in it differed from those who did not.
The masters who excelled in the *Dao’s Virtuous Way* [shànwéi shì] possessed talents reaching the heavens, their aspirations aligned with the Dao and the Divine, their wisdom matched the heavens, and their penetration the Sage’s.
So profound as to be unmeasurable, they were subtle, wondrous, profound, and penetrating—deep beyond recognition.
For they were unseen in form, the Dao had no shape, and could not be perceived by the eyes—only known subtly, hence their unity with the Dao.
This is what the *Book of Documents* [Shū] meant by *"The Dao’s heart is but subtle."* [dàoxīn wéi wēi]
The Divine’s wondrousness is without desire—only those who enter wondrousness can know it, for it cannot be sought with fixed expectations.
This is what the *Book of Changes* [Yì] meant by *"The Divine is wondrous in all things."* [shén miào wànwù]
Profoundity [yuān] as the heavens’ hue bears both *qi* [chì] and *essence* [yáng], for it can embrace both yin and yang.
Thus, the heavens’ color is in this, as the *Book of Changes* [Yì] says: *"The heavens are profound, and the earth is vast."* [tiān xuán ér dì huáng]
If one can be profound and vast, then one aligns with the heavens.
Penetration [tōng] means unrestricted passage—nothing can obstruct it.
Thus, the Sage’s work is in this, as the *Commentary* [Zhuàn] says: *"There is no obstruction in all things—this is called the Sage."* [shì wú bù tōng zhī wéi shèng]
If one aligns with the *Great Penetration* [Dàtōng], then one enters the Sage’s domain.
The ancient masters of the *Dao’s Virtuous Way* [shànwéi shì], subtle, wondrous, profound, and penetrating—so deep as to be unrecognizable—are like the heavens and earth.
As the following passage states, they are but named in approximation.
*"Cautious as one crossing a river in winter,
hesitant as if fearing four neighbors."*

The Emperor Huizong’s annotation states:
*"Cautious"* [yù] means to plan rest before action.
*"Hesitant"* [yóu] means to consider doubt after completion.
The ancient ones who embodied the Dao took inner cultivation as their duty, not outer penetration as their delight.
They lived in constant fear and reflection, acting only when compelled—like crossing a river in winter, guarding without loss.
As if fearing four neighbors, this is what the *Book of Changes* [Yì] means by *"With this, one purifies and restrains."* [yǐ cǐ zhī jièjiè]

The *Explanatory Commentary* [Shūyì] states:
To plan before an event is called *cautious* [yù], hence *cautious* means to plan rest before action.
To plan after an event is called *hesitant* [yóu], hence *hesitant* means to consider doubt after completion.
The ancient ones who embodied the Dao took inner cultivation as their duty, not outer penetration as their ultimate goal.
They found forgetfulness of things as good, not delight in mastering things.
In constant fear and reflection, they dared not indulge—
before an event’s arrival, they responded only when moved, acted only when pressed, rising only when compelled.
Thus, they planned before events, like crossing a river in winter.

chunks.original_text: 於事之已成者，怵然为戒，视为止，行为迟，后事而图，若畏四邻。 盖川者难之所在，冬而涉之，人所病也，若冬涉川，岂得已哉？ 邻者比而恤己，使之相保，人所善也，若畏四邻，岂失己哉？ 然则有而为其可易耶？ 《易》言：君子将有为，将有行，必先斋戒以神明其德。 盖谓此也。 俨若容， 徽宗注曰：《语》曰：望之俨然。 《记》曰：俨若思。 庄子曰：物无道，正容以悟之，使人之意也消。 全德之人，远之则有望，近之则不厌， 故其状义而不朋。 疏义曰：入而与物辨，则堕肢体，寓百骸，而其形为可践； 出而与物交，则布乎四体，形乎动静，而容止为可观。 俨若容，则出而交物，容止可观之时也。 《语》所谓望之俨然，《记》所谓俨□ 若思，皆此意也。 庄子曰：物无道，正容以悟之，使人之意也消。 盖全德之人貌允空虚，与人并立而使人化，况见於动容貌之际乎，正其衣冠，尊其瞻视，远之则有望，在彼为无恶，近之则不厌，在此为无斁，则其使人之意也消，固不难矣。 古之真人其状义而不朋，曷尝胁肩谄笑，以自招其辱哉？ 涣若冰将释， 徽宗注曰：水凝而为冰，冰释而为水，其实一体。 蔽於执一者，如水之凝； 通於大同者，如冰之释。 《易》曰：涣，离也。 遗物离人而无所系輆，所以为涣。 疏义曰：水至清而结冰不清，神至明而结形不明。 阴凝之而为冰，犹神之化形也。 阳释之而为水，犹形之化神也。 水之与冰，其实一体。 蔽於执一者，知守形而不知尽神，故如水之凝，生於水而遏水。 通於大同者，知忘形而能与於神，故如冰之释，泛然而无留碍也。 《易》於风行水上为泱，而《说卦》以谓涣离也，则泱之为义，以离物遗人而无系较故也。 惟离物遗人，则若冰解冻释矣，孰有系较者乎？ 与夫其寒凝冰者，固有间矣。 《太元》曰无所系较者，圣也。 涣若冰将释，所以通有以入圣欤？ 敦兮其若朴， 徽宗注曰：敦者，厚之至。 性本至厚，如木之朴，未散为器。 疏义曰：《易》所谓敦仁言於仁为至厚，《记》所谓教化言於化为至厚，则敦者厚之至也。 惟民生厚则性本厚矣，因物有迁则厚者薄矣。 惟善为士者，复性之本，不与物迁，则如木之朴，朴而围之，有象可见，未形为器，其厚可谓至矣。 与夫以斤斲之，析其浑全，破为牺尊，青黄而文之，盖有间矣。 旷兮其若谷， 徽宗注曰：旷者，广之极。 心原无际，如谷之虚，受而能应。 疏义曰：《诗》所谓旷野，言其地之至广，《传》所谓旷日，言其时之至广，则旷者广之极也。 方寸与太虚齐空，则心原无际矣。 无所不包，实无所包，则其室常虚矣。 惟善为士者，政虚之极，尽心之真，如谷之能受，受而不积，如谷之能应，应而不着，其广可谓至也。 与夫六凿相攘，自狭其居，以实妨道，动辄有碍，盖有间矣。 浑兮其若浊。 徽宗注曰：不刿雕以为康，不矫激以为异，浑然而已，故若浊。 与修身以明污者异矣。 疏义曰：至人之游世，和光而同尘，毁方而丸合，大廉不嗛，行非刻制，未尝刿雕以为康也。 不多辟异，为在从众，未常矫激以为异也。 行险而顺，与物宛转，不立圭角，浑然而已。 众人昭昭，我独若昏，似浊而非浊也，与修身以明污者异矣。
chunks.translated_text:
For matters already accomplished, one stands in solemn warning—
vision becomes still, action becomes slow,
planning comes after the deed,
as though fearing one’s neighbors.

For the river is where danger lies,
and crossing in winter is what people dread—
if one crosses in winter, how could it be otherwise?
Neighbors are those who stand close and care for one another,
ensuring mutual protection—
if one fears one’s neighbors, how could one lose oneself?

Yet then, is there anything that can be easily attained?
The *Book of Changes* says:
*"When the gentleman is about to act or move,
he must first purify and refine his virtue/power to manifest its clarity."*

This is what it means.

**Solemn as in reverence,**
Huizong’s annotation:
*The Analects* says: *"Gazing upon him, he appears solemn."*
*The Records* says: *"Solemn, as though in thought."*
Zhuangzi says: *"Things have no inherent Dao—
rectify one’s bearing to awaken them,
so that people’s intentions dissolve."*

The fully virtuous/powerful one—
from afar, he inspires awe;
up close, he does not weary.
Thus his demeanor is upright yet unassuming.

The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
When entering and distinguishing among things,
one risks entanglement in limbs and bones,
and the body becomes something to be trodden upon.
When exiting and interacting with things,
one manifests in movement and stillness,
and one’s bearing and posture become observable.
**Solemn as in reverence**—
this is the moment of exiting to interact with things,
when bearing and posture are fit to be observed.
*The Analects’* *"Gazing upon him, he appears solemn,"*
and *The Records’* *"Solemn, as though in thought"*
both convey this meaning.

Zhuangzi says: *"Things have no inherent Dao—
rectify one’s bearing to awaken them,
so that people’s intentions dissolve."*
Indeed, the fully virtuous/powerful one’s appearance is utterly simple and empty,
standing beside others and transforming them—
what more, when seen in gestures and expressions?
Adjusting his garments and dignifying his gaze,
from afar, he inspires awe—
for others, this means no ill intent;
up close, he does not weary—
for himself, this means no exhaustion.
Thus his power to transform others is effortless.
The ancient *True Persons* were upright yet unassuming—
how could they ever slouch and fawn to invite humiliation?

**Dissolving like ice about to thaw,**
Huizong’s annotation:
*"Water congeals to form ice, ice melts back to water—
in essence, they are one."*

Those ensnared by one-sidedness
are like water congealing;
those attuned to the Great Unity
are like ice thawing.
The *Book of Changes* says:
*"Dissolving—separation."*
To abandon things and people without attachment—
this is what it means to dissolve.

The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
Water, though clear, freezes into unclean ice;
the spirit, though luminous, solidifies into an opaque form.
Yin congeals to form ice—
just as the spirit manifests as form.
Yang melts to become water—
just as form returns to the spirit.
Water and ice are one in essence.

Those ensnared by one-sidedness
know only to guard the form and not to exhaust the spirit,
thus like water congealing—
born from water yet obstructing its flow.
Those attuned to the Great Unity
know to forget the form and merge with the spirit,
thus like ice thawing—
spreading freely without hindrance.

The *Book of Changes* pairs wind over water as *"Dissolving"* in *Hexagram Variations*,
yet in *Appended Commentary* it says *"Dissolving—separation."*
Thus *"Dissolving"* in meaning
refers to abandoning things and people without attachment.
Only by abandoning things and people
does one dissolve like ice thawing—
who then would have attachments?
Compared to the frozen, rigid ice,
the difference is vast.

*The Great Origin* says: *"Without attachments—this is the Sage."*
**Dissolving like ice about to thaw**—
is this not the way to enter Sagehood?

**Thick as in sincerity, like uncarved wood,**
Huizong’s annotation:
*"Thick" is the utmost of depth.
Nature is originally profound,
like wood before it is shaped into vessels.*

The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
The *Book of Changes* speaks of *"thick virtue"*—
virtue as the utmost depth;
*The Records* speaks of *"thick teaching"*—
teaching as the utmost depth.
Thus *"thick"* is the utmost of depth.

Only when people’s lives are profound
does their nature remain profound.
Yet when they shift with circumstances,
the profound becomes shallow.
Only the virtuous scholar
restores the original nature,
does not shift with things,
and thus is like uncarved wood—
uncarved yet encircled with visible grain,
not yet shaped into a vessel,
its depth truly profound.
Compared to hewing it with an axe,
splitting its wholeness,
carving it into sacrificial vessels,
and painting it with green and yellow—
the difference is vast.

**Vast as in emptiness, like a valley,**
Huizong’s annotation:
*"Vast" is the extreme of breadth.
The heart originally has no bounds,
like a valley’s emptiness—
receiving and responding without limit.*

The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
*The Odes* speaks of *"vast wilderness"*—
referring to land’s utmost breadth;
*The Commentary* speaks of *"vast days"*—
referring to time’s utmost breadth.
Thus *"vast"* is the extreme of breadth.

When the inch of the heart aligns with the boundless void,
the heart originally has no limits.
Without boundaries yet not confined,
its chamber remains ever empty.
Only the virtuous scholar,
at the peak of emptiness,
exhausts the truth of the heart,
like a valley’s ability to receive—
receiving without accumulation,
like a valley’s ability to respond—
responding without attachment.
Its breadth is truly profound.
Compared to the six orifices clashing,
narrowing one’s dwelling,
and obstructing the Dao with solidity—
the difference is vast.

**Undifferentiated as in turbidity.**
Huizong’s annotation:
*"Not carved nor polished to achieve harmony,
not exaggerated to stand out—
undifferentiated, yet complete, like turbidity."*

This differs from those who refine themselves to reveal impurity.

The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
The Perfect One’s way in the world
is to blend light with dust,
to rectify angles and round them,
to be greatly modest without resentment,
to act without rigid rules—
never carving nor polishing to achieve harmony.
Not seeking distinction,
they follow the common—
never exaggerating to stand out.
Moving with danger yet yielding,
adapting to things with flexibility,
not erecting rigid corners,
undifferentiated, yet complete.

While others are bright and clear,
I alone appear muddled—
seeming turbid yet not turbid.
This differs from those who refine themselves to reveal impurity.

chunks.original_text: 孰能浊以静之徐清？ 孰能安以动之徐生？ 徽宗注曰：有道之士，即动而静，时骋而要其宿，定而能应，至无而供其求。 故静之徐清而物莫能浊，动之徐生而物莫能安。 《易》曰：来徐徐。 徐者，安行而自适之意。 至人之用心，非以静止为善，而有意於静； 非以生出为功，而有为于生也。 因其固然，付之自尔，而无休迫之情、遑遽之劳，故曰徐清。 静之徐清，万物无足以挠其心，故孰能浊？ 动之徐生，万物无足以系其虑，故孰能安？ 安有止之意，为物所系，则止矣，岂能应物而不伤。 疏义曰：自豫兮若冬涉川，至浑兮其若浊，应世之述如此，则以体道故也。 惟体道，故动静不失其时，而物莫能累，是以守静为筒。 效物以动，则即动而静，时骋而要其宿，非流於动也，故动而无所逐，物孰能浊？ 有所定矣。 感而遂通，则定而能应，至无以供其求，非胶於静也，故止而无所碍，物孰能安？ 夫物之不能浊，以静之徐清故也。 物之不能安，以动之徐生故也。 静之徐清，非以静止为善，而有意於静也。 虽滥而不失其滥，汨之而常自若焉，万物岂足以挠其心？ 动之徐生，非以生出为功，而有为於生也。 不滞於一隅，时出而应之焉，万物岂足以系其虑？ 盖徐者，安行而自适之意，与《易》言来徐徐同义。 一动一静，因其固然，不悖於理，付之自尔，不拂其性，皆安行而自适，又孰有休迫之恐、遑遽之劳哉？ 安有止之意，作之而不止甚矣，止之而不作亦甚矣。 时作时止，不为物所系，孰能伤之？ 盖为物所系则止矣，恶能应物而不伤？ 保此道者不欲盈。 徽宗注曰：有积也，故不足。 无藏也，故有余？ 至人无积，亦虚而已。 保此道而以天下之美为尽在己者，亦已小矣，故不欲盈。 经曰：大白若辱，广德若不足。 疏义曰：以囷藏禾，禾尽囷虚，以皿藏水，水尽皿虚。 草之盛物，取之如禅； 赞之盛物，有时而匮。 以有积，故不足也。 至无以供万物之求，至虚以应天下之实，以无藏，故有余也。 道运而无积，用之或不盈，至人保此道而无积，亦虚而已。 苟以天下之美为尽在己，是犹擅一壑以自足，亦以小矣。 秋水时至，河伯自喜，所以见笑於大方之家。 经曰：大白若辱，盛德若不足。 岂有满假之累哉？ 夫惟不盈，故能敝不新成。 徽宗注曰：有敝故有新，有成故有坏。 新故相代，如彼四时； 成坏相因，如彼万物。 自道而降丽于形数者，盖莫不然。 惟道无体，虚而不盈，故能敝能新，能成能坏，超然出乎形数之外，而未常敝，未尝坏也。 故曰夫惟不盈，故能敝不新成。 木始荣而终悴，火初明而末熄，以有新也，故敝随之。 曰中则昃，月满则亏，以有成也，故坏继之。 有道者异乎此。 疏义曰：有形则有新敝，有数则有成坏。 春先夏从，更旺更废，运为四时，新故相代者然也。 言唱手执，迭盛迭衰，散为万事，成坏相因者然也。 此皆堕於形数之域，故方新而敝，成已俄坏，莫能进之者。 惟道无体，不囿於形，故能新能敝而未尝敝，不丽於数，故能成能坏而未尝坏，以虚而不盈故也。 今夫木之为物，蕃鲜於春，而摇落於冬，则始荣而终悴也。 火之为物，用之弥明，而扑之则灭，则初明而末熄也。 出一而旦，入六而冥，曰虽为阳之精，未免乎中则昃也。
chunks.translated_text:
Who could make turbidity still to let clarity arise gradually?
Who could make stillness move to let life unfold slowly?

The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
The Daoist adept moves yet remains still,
ranging freely yet returning to their roots,
established yet able to respond,
boundless yet fulfilling all demands.
Thus, when stillness lets clarity arise gradually, nothing can muddy them;
when movement lets life unfold slowly, nothing can unsettle them.

The *Classic of Changes* says:
*"Come slowly, slowly."*
Slowly means to proceed with ease and self-adjustment.

The Perfect One’s use of mind
is not to prize stillness as an end in itself,
nor to labor over life’s emergence as a feat.
Following its natural course,
they entrust it to unfold naturally,
without haste or coercion—
thus clarity arises gradually.
When stillness lets clarity arise gradually,
ten thousand things cannot perturb their mind—
who could muddy them?
When movement lets life unfold slowly,
ten thousand things cannot ensnare their thoughts—
who could unsettle them?

If stillness implies cessation,
being bound by things, then it is cessation—
how could one respond to things without harm?

The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
*"Self-soothing, like winter crossing a river,
utterly undifferentiated, as if turbid—
this is how one embodies the Dao in the world.*
Only by embodying the Dao
does one move and remain still at the right times,
unburdened by things—
thus guarding stillness as a vessel.

Responding to things through movement,
one moves yet remains still,
ranging freely yet returning to their roots—
not lost in movement,
so movement does not scatter them—
who could muddy them?
They are established.
Responding and thus communicating,
established yet able to respond,
boundless yet fulfilling all demands—
not clinging to stillness,
so cessation does not obstruct them—
who could unsettle them?

That things cannot muddy them
is because stillness lets clarity arise gradually.
That things cannot unsettle them
is because movement lets life unfold slowly.

Stillness letting clarity arise gradually
is not to prize stillness as an end in itself,
nor to labor over life’s emergence as a feat.
Though overflowing, they do not lose their overflow,
swept along yet ever self-same—
how could ten thousand things perturb their mind?
Movement letting life unfold slowly
is not to labor over life’s emergence as a feat,
nor to force its emergence.
Not confined to one corner,
they emerge in due time to respond—
how could ten thousand things ensnare their thoughts?

Truly, *slowly* means to proceed with ease and self-adjustment,
in accord with the *Classic of Changes*’ *"Come slowly, slowly."*
Each movement and stillness,
following its natural course,
not contrary to principle,
entrusted to unfold naturally,
not contrary to nature—
all proceed with ease and self-adjustment.
Who then has cause for haste or labor?

If stillness implies cessation,
acting yet not ceasing is extreme,
ceasing yet not acting is also extreme.
Acting and ceasing in due measure,
not bound by things—
who could harm them?
For if bound by things, then it is cessation—
how could one respond to things without harm?

Those who preserve the Dao do not seek fullness.
The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
*"There is accumulation, so there is insufficiency.
There is no hoarding, so there is abundance."*
The Perfect One has no accumulation—
only emptiness.

To preserve the Dao while claiming all the world’s beauty as one’s own
is already small-minded—
thus they do not seek fullness.
The *Classic* says:
*"Great whiteness seems like shame,
vast virtue seems insufficient."*

The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
*"Store grain in a granary—
when the grain is gone, the granary is empty.
Store water in a vessel—
when the water is gone, the vessel is empty.
Grass gathers things—
take from it as you will, yet it remains.
Praises gather things—
yet they sometimes run dry.
Because there is accumulation, there is insufficiency.
The Perfect One, boundless yet fulfilling all demands,
utterly empty yet responding to all reality—
because there is no hoarding, there is abundance.
The Dao flows without accumulation;
its use may not be full—
the Perfect One preserves the Dao without accumulation,
only emptiness.

If one claims all the world’s beauty as one’s own,
it is like monopolizing a ravine to be self-sufficient—
also small-minded.
When autumn waters arrive, the River Spirit rejoices,
yet is laughed at by those of great vision.
The *Classic* says:
*"Great whiteness seems like shame,
vast virtue seems insufficient."*
How could there be the burden of excess?

Only the unfull can renew without ceasing,
can complete without failing.
The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
*"There is accumulation, so there is decay.
There is completion, so there is ruin.
New and decay alternate, like the four seasons;
completion and ruin follow, like all things.
From the Dao descending to forms and numbers,
none escape this.
Only the Dao has no form—
empty yet not full—
thus it can decay and renew,
complete and ruin,
transcending forms and numbers,
yet never decaying, never ruined.
Thus it is said:
Only the unfull can renew without ceasing,
can complete without failing.

Wood begins flourishing yet ends withered,
fire first shines yet finally extinguishes—
because there is renewal, decay follows.
The sun reaches its zenith and declines,
the moon is full and then wanes—
because there is completion, ruin follows.
The Daoist adept differs from this.

The *Explanatory Commentary* states:
*"Form brings renewal and decay,
numbers bring completion and ruin.
Spring precedes summer, waxing then waning—
the cycle of the four seasons follows this.
Speech and action alternate, flourishing then declining—
all affairs follow this.
These all fall within the realm of forms and numbers,
so when new, decay follows;
when complete, ruin comes—
none can escape it.
Only the Dao has no form,
unbound by shape—
thus it can renew and decay yet never decay,
unbound by numbers—
thus it can complete and ruin yet never ruin,
because it is empty yet not full.

Now, wood as a thing
flourishes in spring yet falls in winter—
thus it begins flourishing and ends withered.
Fire as a thing,
the more it is used, the brighter it burns,
yet when extinguished, it is gone—
thus it first shines and finally extinguishes.
Rising at dawn, setting at dusk—
though it is the essence of yang,
it cannot escape midday decline."*
